key_risks: Legal and regulatory risks including employment discrimination lawsuit and shareholder litigation
Operational risks due to dependence on third-party manufacturers and economic sensitivity
Market and competitive risks from intense competition and criticism of business practices
controversies: Pending employment discrimination lawsuit (Lieberman v. Xometry, Inc.)
Investigation by multiple law firms for potential securities fraud
social_issues: Employment practices under scrutiny due to discrimination lawsuit
Partner relations strained by high commission rates and operational practices
governance_issues: Potential securities fraud investigation impacting governance credibility
Cybersecurity risks despite ongoing CMMC Level 2 certification efforts

sources.title: Lieberman v. Xometry, Inc. - UniCourt
sources.snippet: On 06/29/2022 Lieberman filed a Civil Right - Employment Discrimination lawsuit against Xometry, Inc. This case was filed in U.S. District Courts, New York Southern District Court. The Judge overseeing this case is Andrew L. Carter, Jr. The case status is Pending - Other Pending.

sources.title: Xometry's "take" grows to 39% last quarter - Practical Machinist
sources.snippet: I am posting to raise awareness of xometry's business practices, specifically operating at a loss and also taking a huge share from each job. I implore any shop working with them to explore other avenues for business development. Doing business with these people is just cutting off your own legs. There is also a huge risk for their "partner ...

sources.title: Does Anyone Have Opinions on Xometry : r/MechanicalEngineering - Reddit
sources.snippet: Xometry offers more materials, manufacturing processes, and larger part dimensions. This is because they outsource ALL work. They are ok. Don't expect the best work every time, but they can get things done eventually. Expect to "work with them" to get things done, but perhaps less so than a local job-shop.

sources.title: Xometry : r/Machinists - Reddit
sources.snippet: The way xometry works is that the job starts off with like a 70+% cut going to xometry, and the price you see is their 'first offer'. You can tell them the price that you will do it for, and they may increase it. I did a job on there that was initially listed for 677, but I got paid 1800 for it, and xometry still got 20% I believe.

sources.title: Feedback on Xometry for small machine shop? : r/Machinists - Reddit
sources.snippet: Joined Xometry's partner program as it seems like a good way to start getting some work. A few days in, I'm still only able to do 1 job at a time due to partner restrictions. It looks like the jobs are a bit hit or miss in terms of profitability. Some are ok, others pay less than material and finishing cost.

sources.title: experience with Xometry? : r/Machinists - Reddit
sources.snippet: Xometry or another will be my next choice to get a more reasonable price with an expectation of a hit on quality. I expect $30-40 through them. Once In a while a part hits production or a test needs larger order runs. I have had wild success with Xometry on some slightly larger parts orders (qty 10ish) I needed basically next day.

sources.title: Are my uploaded files and Xometry projects secure?
sources.snippet: Xometry values your privacy and security. You always own your data, and Xometry only uses it to estimate, fabricate, and review customer-specific projects.
